body.p:
Your esteemed favor is at hand, also
the August number of the Occident; I trust the general
contents may cause men to see the necessity of making
some improvements in our Synagogue goverment.

Since I last wrote you, Rev S Jacobs has been
here and he will in all probability be the minister
of KKSI. as over Thirty members including M Levin
and M Valentine have pledged themselves to vote for him.
To the great injustice of any other candidate who may
be on the way to apply for the situation. I begin
to see now that those gentlemen who made objections
to your being our minister on account of your personal
inconvenience?, know more about the vacillating character
of the Congregation, and had your interest more at heart
that I gave them credit for. They pledged themselves
to you, and notwithstanding your declining to become
a candidate, if they really wanted you they should
at the Election have voted for you at all events for
the first ballots the converse was the case on receipt of your
letter they no longer considered themselves bound, and almost
immediately, transferred their preference for Dr Eckman
a number sufficient to elect him, was obtained
(not by me for I took no ostensible part in it.)
M Valentine intended to call a caucus meeting to
get those persons to pledge themselves to elect him

— in mean time Mr Jacobs appears on the Japir?
on his way to Mobile. He is invited to preach
and to say the prayers, his manner of reading
and his delivery oratorical powers giving
satisfaction to the people, without any more
ado.—they at once confer with him, induce him
not to proceed to Mobile, and at an informal meeting
unanimously invite him (Mr Levin in the chair) to
become a candidate, and as a guarantee, that
they will elect him, provided him with a paper
signed by over thirty members pledging themselves
to that effect. Mr Leeser & Dr Eckman thrown
under the Table. I told Mr Jacobs that I could
not advocate his election in the first place I have
no vote and if I had it would be cast first
for yourself and if you could not be elected I would
then vote for Dr. E. Saml Hart Sen. & Hyman Hart
then present at the meeting but took no part except
to say that their action was doing injustice to
other candidates who might intend to apply.

— Comment is unnerving and you are better away
from them; I enclose you a letter recd yesterday
from Mr Henry by Mr Valentine, I requested it of him
and I send it to you that you may “Prepare” as
the congregation do not intend to act in the matter
so says Valentine, at same time I would advise that
you remain perfectly silent.
“entre nous” Yesterday I recd a letter from New Orleans
from one of the Trustees of K. K. Dispersed of Israel

informing me that Rev M N Nathan had voluntary
resigned his office as minister, and requesting me to
inform Dr Eckman of this fact and to invite him
to become a candidate apply for the situation
as If they can procure a minister without advertising
they would prefer it no reason being assigned
for the resignation of Mr Nathan. Dr Eckman
has written to Mr Nathan to know from him
whether his resignation is permanent or whether
he would again resume office if matters were
accommodated to him, as he would not interrupt
or make application, without he first was certain
of this fact. Should such be the case, and
you do not intend to apply, your influence ?
the President S Kursheet might have some weight
to induce them to accept him, I take it for granted
that they have not offered you the situation as my
letter is from one of the Trustees. Mr Myer Simpson

I should like to see the Doctor in a proper position
when his usefulness could be made available,
the more I see and know of him the more impressed
I am with the importance of his mission to Israel.
He is preparing a continuation of his article for
the Occident save room for it it will be on in a
few days.

remember me to our friend S.S. and Lady and
all friends. I intended to have written more but
I am called of. Yours Sincerely
